;;N;;o 公司是;一座岛屿。所有人都签订合同并与他人竞争。相反，当老板们决定某种特定的关系可以通过法令更好地管理时，一家公司可能会收购另一家公司。在这两个极点之间，企业有很多方法可以结合资本、知识或其他资源，而无需完全结合在一起。

;

;这种介于两者之间的方法从科技和人工智能 (;AI;); ; 到汽车制造和能源，这些安排正在赢得整个经济领域的青睐。据咨询公司 Ankura 称，虽然企业收购在 2023 年陷入停滞，但合资企业 (;JV;) 和合伙企业的数量却猛增了 40%。它们在技术快速变革的领域和保护主义盛行的地方尤其受欢迎，而保护主义如今同样困扰着富国和穷国。随着商业壁垒的增加、高利率的持续困扰以及监管机构对收购的严厉限制，这种联络正在成为扩大商业帝国的首选方式，迪士尼、福特和微软等公司最近的行动就表明了这一点。称之为准合并时代。

;;

;再见，合作。大家好，团队

;

;当今更加复杂的世界正在导致更加复杂的安排。一个热点再次是汽车制造。由于从内燃机汽车向电动汽车（;EV;）的转变以及中国汽车制造商在市场上占据主导地位而引发的去工业化担忧，该行业正在经历重塑。去年10月，由菲亚特克莱斯勒与标致和雪铁龙母公司PSA集团于2021年合并而成的Stellantis宣布收购零跑汽车20%的股份并成立合资公司>; 在国外制造和销售中国<小型>;电动汽车;制造商的汽车。 （Stellantis 的最大股东还部分拥有《经济学人》的母公司。）下个月，雷诺和日产批准了一项新的、更宽松的协议，交叉持股更加平等。 3 月份，日产和另一家日本竞争对手本田表示，他们正在探索建立战略合作伙伴关系来开发 ;EV;。

;

;许多新的汽车制造企业并不是为了制造汽车——至少不是直接制造汽车。去年，Stellantis 收购了一家小型矿商 McEwen Copper 近 20% 的股份，作为在阿根廷开采红色金属的交易（其中还涉及巨头力拓集团）的一部分。这些铜最终可能会运往印第安纳州科科莫，在那里，Stellantis 拥有与三星 ;SDI; 共同建设的两座电池工厂的 49% 股份，三星 SDI 是一家韩国电池公司，由同名电子巨头部分持股。 。 Stellantis 也是 ;IONNA; 的一部分，这是一家由七家汽车制造商组成的 ;JV ;，计划在美国建造 30,000 个充电站。

;微软、;AI;AI; 合作； 130 亿美元之后，它正在将 Open;AI; 的模型集成到其消费者和企业产品中。在这家初创公司动荡的阴影下，微软已经开始扩大赌注。

;

;2 月份宣布的对 Mistral 的 1600 万美元投资可能很小，但有助于将法国成为<小>;人工智能;超级大国的最佳机会带入微软的轨道。更有创意的是，今年 3 月，微软通过一项“无协议”协议震惊了科技界，另一家模型制造商 Inflection ;AI; 的高级员工; ;跳槽到了微软。据报道，该初创公司的其他投资者正在通过一份不寻常的许可协议获得补偿。 （Inflection 的一位创始人是《经济学人》母公司的董事会成员。）微软 15 亿美元的 ;G;42 交易一半是合作关系，一半是高风险外交——这笔交易希望美国和阿联酋政府;在;人工智能;方面进行更密切的合作。;

;

;准并购浪潮能否成功很难预测。尽管联盟比收购更容易通过监管机构和政治家的监管，但它们仍然可能会陷入困境。去年，美国航空和另一家航空公司捷蓝航空在被司法部起诉后终止了在美国东海岸的联盟。迪士尼的新体育事业正在受到反垄断裁判的密切关注。今年早些时候，另一家美国反垄断警察联邦贸易委员会对<小>;人工智能;交易展开调查。欧洲和英国监管机构也发出了类似的声音。

;

;跨境交易尤其走上一条狭窄的道路。在新兴经济体的合作始终需要谨慎管理，以免有政治联系的当地公司向外国合作伙伴发起攻击，或者整个司法管辖区变得无法投资。西方对自由市场的背离在某种程度上使这种政治不确定性全球化了。合伙企业或合资企业固有的灵活性，但缺乏全面收购，可能会使这种结构在政治上更容易被接受。但即使是为避免绊倒电线而精心设计的交易也可能受到审查。尽管;宁德时代;与福特的合作不涉及这家中国公司的股权投资，但这并没有阻止美国立法者呼吁严格审查该交易。

;难怪争议不断一分钱十个。今年三月，一位美国法官裁定沃尔玛可以终止与第一资本的合作关系，因为沃尔玛和信用卡提供商因协议条款发生争执。一场令人担忧的语言棋游戏让石油工业陷入了困境。埃克森美孚正在与较小的竞争对手赫斯交战，如果赫斯将自己出售给埃克森美孚的竞争对手美国超级巨头雪佛龙，他们在圭亚那的;合资企业;会发生什么。

;;A ;;印度进行投票;，总理纳伦德拉·莫迪可以夸耀;世界上规模最大的选举;正在其增长最快的主要经济体中举行。印度的<小>;国内生产总值;为 3.5 万亿美元，目前位居世界第五，高于其前殖民统治者英国。政府正在大力投资公路、铁路、港口、能源和数字基础设施。许多奉行“中国加一”战略以实现供应链多元化的跨国公司，都将印度视为未提及的“一国”。这种经济势头必将帮助莫迪赢得第三个任期。根据一些独立预测，当他再过五年左右完成这项任务时，印度的;GDP;可能会达到 6 万亿美元，成为世界第三大经济体。

;

;但印度很容易过早得意忘形。它过去曾享受过这样的乐观时刻，但现在却把它们浪费掉了。与许多道路一样，它的经济记录也充满了坑洼。它的人民仍然严重就业不足。尽管其人口最近超过了中国，但其劳动力规模仅为中国的76%。 （女性加入劳动力市场的比例与沙特阿拉伯大致相同。）与 2008 年全球金融危机之前相比，私营企业的投资在<小>;GDP;中所占的比例仍然较小。莫迪上台后，印度的人均收入只有中国的五分之一（按市场汇率计算）。今天它仍然是相同的分数。这六本书有助于描绘印度曲折的经济历程，并评估莫迪先生喜忧参半的经济记录。

;;

;;打破陈规：重新构想印度的经济未来.; 作者：Raghuram Rajan 和 Rohit Lamba。 ;企鹅业务;； 336页； 49.99 美元

;

;在莫迪先生上任之前，印度是新兴市场“脆弱五国”集团中一个不幸的成员。印度能够逃离这个俱乐部在很大程度上要归功于拉古拉姆·拉詹(Raghuram Rajan)，他在2013年至2016年期间领导了该国央行。在这本书中，他和宾夕法尼亚州立大学的兰巴先生对印度经济“彻底”的乐观和悲观论调表达了不耐烦。他们提出了具有挑衅性的论点，即印度不应该渴望成为像中国一样的制造业强国（他们称之为“假中国”），这既是因为印度本质上是不同的，也是因为世界已经发生了变化。印度的土地更难被征用，其劳动力更难被剥削。技术进步也使得服务业更容易出口，制造业的就业来源也变得不那么丰富。他们的书中充满了他们认为可以在印度蓬勃发展的行业的钢笔肖像，包括芯片设计、远程教育以及精心包装的;idli;面糊。两位作者都对印度转向压倒性的多数主义感到遗憾，他们认为这最终将抑制其创造力，从而抑制其经济前景。尽管如此，这是一部略显乐观的作品。

;

;;新印度：夺回失去的荣耀。;作者：Arvind Panagariya。 ;牛津大学出版社;； 288 页

;

;这本书为“打破常规”提供了有用的陪衬。阿尔文德·帕纳加里亚 (Arvind Panagariya) 从哥伦比亚大学离职，担任莫迪先生设立的政府智库负责人，以取代旧的计划委员会。作者毫不吝惜地赞扬了首相，也毫不留情地蔑视了他所推翻的国大党领导的政府。帕纳加里亚先生还对劳动密集型制造业创造印度急需的就业机会的潜力充满信心。他借用了毛时代中国的一句话，认为这个国家必须两条腿走路——制造业和服务业。为此，它应该简化劳动法，保持卢比的竞争力，并将关税合理化在 7% 左右。该书还增加了一系列其他改革（包括提高通胀目标、拍卖未使用的政府土地以及取消农作物价格下限），这些改革将使莫迪先生无论在位多久都保持忙碌。

;

;;2008-18 失去的十年：印度的增长故事如何演变成没有故事的增长。;作者：Puja Mehra。 ;Ebury Press；; 360 页； $21

;

;Rajan 先生和 Panagariya 先生都出现在这本详尽报道的 2008 年至 2018 年印度经济政策制定的报告中。Mehra 女士，一位财经记者描述了前任政府的腐败和误判以及莫迪第一任期的失望。这位总理非常关注政治威胁，但对更迫在眉睫的经济危险却感到沾沾自喜。例如，在拉詹和其他人揭露了印度企业巨头不良贷款的真实规模后，他的政府在满足印度公共部门银行所需资金方面进展缓慢。一名公务员讲述了漫长而沉闷的会议，莫迪在会上监督他零碎的福利计划，尽管更深层次的改革陷入了停滞。 “唯一要做的就是把所有的花生和;chana;都吃掉。”

;

;;亿万富翁拉杰：印度之旅新镀金时代。; 作者：詹姆斯·克拉布特里。寰宇一家出版物;； ;416 页； $7.97

;

;要仔细了解这些企业巨头，请阅读前金融界人士 James Crabtree 所著的《亿万富翁 Raj》次。序言描述了一辆阿斯顿·马丁超级跑车在深夜发生的神秘事故，这辆汽车是印度首富穆克什·安巴尼 (Mukesh Ambani) 旗下的信实集团 (Reliance) 旗下子公司注册的。即使在一名员工自首之后，关于驾驶者是谁的谣言仍在流传。警方告诉克拉布特里先生，这辆车已被扣押进行测试。但他发现它被遗弃在警察局外的路边，藏在塑料布下。几个月后它仍然在那里。克拉布特里先生接着揭露了印度其他“大佬”的成就、愚蠢行为和影响力。其中包括翠鸟啤酒和航空公司的前所有者维杰·马尔亚 (Vijay Mallya)。他曾被称为“美好时光之王”，后来因金融犯罪而面临引渡到英国。克拉布特里先生在细雨蒙蒙的伦敦与他会面，这位受过教训的享乐主义者只是“稍微迟到”了采访。作者的新闻直觉只有一次失败了。他收到了高塔姆·阿达尼 (Gautam Adani) 儿子的婚礼邀请函。这位备受争议的亿万富翁因与莫迪关系密切以及对令人瞠目结舌的债务水平的了解而闻名。这场狂欢可能值得在本书中占有一章。但克拉布特里先生不习惯陌生人的婚礼请柬，因此拒绝参加。

;

;;不平等：为什么印度落后于邻国。; 作者：Swati Narayan。 ;上下文;； 370 页； 35.99 美元

;

;斯瓦蒂·纳拉扬 (Swati Narayan) 的书远离宝利加克 (Bollygarchs) 或德里各部委的浮华，描绘了她在印度南部村庄的社会学田野调查及其与孟加拉国和尼泊尔的边境。她解决了“南亚之谜”：为什么印度的一些较贫穷的邻国（及其一些南部邦）在健康、教育、营养和卫生等许多社会指标上超过了印度的中心地带。孟加拉国女孩的预期寿命比印度长，而且体重不足的人数较少。她的论点用一大堆统计数据和引人注目的小插曲来说明：比哈尔邦废弃的诊所、尼泊尔的分娩中心以及南部喀拉拉邦设备齐全的儿童保育中心。在孟加拉国边境的一个村庄，农民嘲笑他们的印度邻居仍然在田里排便。她详细描述了种姓、阶级、宗教和性别的残酷分歧，这些分歧仍然压迫着印度许多人，破坏了社会进步所需的共同目标。

;

;;如何英国的统治改变了印度的经济：国王的悖论。;作者：Tirthankar Roy。 ;施普林格国际;； 159 页； 69.99 美元

;

;许多评论家将大英帝国描述为一台不断榨干印度财富的机器。但这可能给了它太多的信任。英属印度政府出人意料地小、权宜之计，而且常常效率低下。伦敦经济学院的蒂坦卡·罗伊指出，它的收入过于依赖土地，很少超过<小>;GDP;的7%。与之前的莫卧儿帝国相比，它在基础设施上的支出更多，而在奢侈品上的支出更少。但它忽视了医疗保健和教育。从 1914 年到 1947 年，印度的人均 GDP 几乎没有增长。罗伊先生揭示了印度内部的巨大差异，而这种差异被该死的平均水平所掩盖。英国致力于全球化的“商业帝国”有利于沿海商业，但导致乡村贫困和停滞。不幸的是，对于农村群众来说，从农村搬到城市从来都不是一件容易的事。事实上，罗伊先生在这本书中列出的有关印度经济过去的一些社会流动障碍在有关其未来的书籍中仍然很突出。

;What is clear is that, in the early hours of April 19th, Iran activated its air defences at an air base near the central city of Isfahan. It also temporarily grounded flights in Isfahan and several other locations, including the capital, Tehran. Unnamed American officials leaked that Israel had fired missiles at its longtime foe, though other reports point to it using a small number of drones.

;

;Iran sought to downplay the incident. A state-television correspondent told viewers that everything was calm in Isfahan and that the explosions heard by residents were from Iranian air defences, not incoming projectiles. A spokesman for Iran's space agency said that three small drones had been shot down and the attack foiled. Social-media accounts linked to the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (;IRGC;) circulated stock photos of tiny quadcopters to mock the size of the attack.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Oil markets shrugged it off too. The price of Brent crude jumped by more than $3, to above $90 a barrel, amid the first reports of explosions in Iran. As more details emerged, though, it pared those gains, and by mid-afternoon in the Middle East it was trading slightly below the previous day's price.

;

;Isfahan is home to a missile-production complex that researches and builds many of Iran's ballistic weapons. It also houses some of Iran's ;F;-14s, which are half a century old but are still among the most sophisticated fighter jets in its arsenal. There was thus a certain symmetry in the tit-for-tat strikes, since Iran's barrage aimed ballistic missiles at an Israeli air base that hosts the country's advanced ;F;-35 jets.

;

;The city is also home to parts of Iran's clandestine nuclear programme (though the most important bits are elsewhere). In recent years Iran has produced an ever-larger stash of enriched uranium, some of it to near weapons-grade. Early rumours that Israel had targeted nuclear facilities on April 19th seem inaccurate, however. The International Atomic Energy Agency said there was “no damage” to Iran's nuclear sites.

;

;Some Iranian analysts have questioned the quadcopter story. Such drones have a range of only a few kilometres, while Isfahan is more than 300km from any land or sea border (and 1,500km from Israel). But they have been used before as part of shadowy attacks on arms factories in Iran—presumably deployed by Israeli agents inside the country.

;

;Given the scale of the Iranian attack on April 13th, it was all but certain that Israel would retaliate. It had a range of options, from a major strike that matched Iran's in scale to covert operations or cyber-attacks. By choosing direct yet symbolic action it hopes to strike a balance: signalling that it is capable of hitting Iran and not deterred from doing so, but without forcing Iran to hit back. Israel deviated from its usual policy and notified America of the plan in advance. It hopes to preserve the American-led coalition, which includes several Arab countries, that helped it fend off the Iranian missiles and drones.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Hours before the apparent Israeli strike Hossein Amirabdollahian, the Iranian foreign minister, told ;CNN; that his country's response to any further Israeli attack would be “immediate and at a maximum level”. By pretending no attack even happened, Iran buys room to manoeuvre. Still, behind the scenes, some hawks—like Amir Ali Hajizadeh, the head of the ;IRGC;'s missile force—are probably urging a response.

;

;Even if this round is over, though, both countries may be unable to go back to fighting in the shadows. Iran raised the stakes by launching a direct attack from its territory—setting a new precedent the next time Israel tries to assassinate members of the ;IRGC;. This is yet another complication for Israel's war cabinet, which is already planning an attack on Hamas's last remaining stronghold in Gaza and a possible campaign against Hizbullah in Lebanon.

;

;It took a series of tempestuous cabinet meetings, and at least two aborted operations, until the Israelis decided on their response against Iran. Binyamin Netanyahu, the prime minister, is operating within narrow constraints. His international allies, led by America, have been urging restraint. Meanwhile some of his ministers have called for a more devastating move.

;

;They have been told to keep mum about the strike on April 19th. But Itamar Ben-Gvir, the far-right national-security minister, posted a single word on social media—;dardale;—a term which, in Israeli sport, refers to a half-hearted and harmless kick towards the other side's goal. Such goading is meant to pressure Mr Netanyahu not only to take more forceful action against Iran, but also to escalate operations in Gaza, where Israel's deployment is at its smallest in the past six months. The prime minister may be cautious about the former, lest he overstretch Israel's army and anger its allies.

;

;The latter is more likely. An offensive in Rafah, a city where an estimated 1.5m displaced Palestinians are now huddled, would almost certainly cause large numbers of casualties. It has so far been delayed by international pressure, but the Israeli army is now making preparations to drop leaflets calling on civilians to leave Rafah for “safe areas” (which are not yet equipped to handle an influx of desperate people). Not for the first time, the people of Gaza may have to pay for the Iranian-Israeli conflict.;■;

;< span data-caps="initial">;N;;ATURE IS TREATING; Americans to all kinds of spectacles. On April 8th millions witnessed a ;total solar eclipse;. Many will be less charmed when, in the coming days, trillions of cicadas appear in the country's Midwest and south-east. The swarm will be unusually large because two types of the bug—Brood XIII and Brood XIX—are emerging simultaneously. The last time they appeared at the same time was in 1803, when Thomas Jefferson was president. Why do the cicadas have such an unusual life cycle?

;

;Brood XIX appears every 13 years; Brood XIII every 17. During that time cicada nymphs remain underground, feeding on sap from tree roots until their biological alarm clocks go off. The temperature determines precisely when cicadas come out; the soil temperature eight inches deep must reach around 18°C. When that happens, usually sometime in May, they mature, emerge, mate, lay eggs if female, and then die—all in four to six weeks.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Biologists believe that the strange lifestyle of periodical cicadas is an example of a survival strategy called “predator satiation”. The insects emerge in such prodigious quantities that predators, such as birds and rodents, cannot possibly eat them all. Their prime-numbered life cycles may also help cicadas avoid damaging synchronisation with the two- and three-year population fluctuations of their predators. An abundance of prey allows predators to reproduce in greater numbers, so for example birds with a life cycle that is a factor of the cicadas' would be in abundance the next time they emerged. This could establish a rhythm resulting in lots of predators regularly being around in years when there were lots of prey.

;

;Female cicadas lay their eggs in the branches of a tree. When they hatch two weeks later, the larvae fall to the ground. Next they tunnel down to the tree's roots, from which they suck out their sustenance. If a female chooses poorly and the tree dies in the years before the larvae reach maturity, her offspring will perish. They will also do badly if the tree has old, gnarled roots, rather than young, succulent ones. This may explain why cicadas thrive in suburban areas, where trees tend to be young, healthy and face less competition for resources than they might in a thicket.

;

;The coming insect storm will worry orchard owners, whose trees can be weakened by cicadas. Other than that the bugs will do little harm—besides making a mess, and infuriating insomniacs with their incessant, piercing chorus. The super-swarm will also provide an opportunity for entomologists to learn more about the creatures. Gene Kritsky, a biologist at Mount St Joseph University in Cincinnati, has developed an app called Cicada Safari through which the public can upload sightings, helping to map the bugs' emergence. The sound of smartphone-cameras snapping may soon be audible alongside the cicadas' calls. ;■;

;

;Some art historians regard Kollwitz, who died in 1945, as a virtuoso on a par with Dürer and Rembrandt. During her life her work was published in magazines and exhibited in galleries; ;across the West, but it has since been largely overlooked.哈佛大学现代艺术教授玛丽亚·高夫表示，在过去一个世纪的大部分时间里，“批评界都对她冷遇”。 Two major exhibitions, at the Museum of Modern Art (;M;o;MA;) in New York and the Staedel Museum in Frankfurt, aim to change that.

;

;In the past critics argued that Kollwitz was “a pessimistic painter of suffering”. It is true that her subjects were human figures caught in the pain of war or poverty, but both exhibitions show that the artist was radical in both vision and medium. Like Charles Dickens, whose novels she read, she sought to capture the pain of those left behind by a rapidly modernising society and to portray life as “true and genuine and untinted” as possible. As she wrote in her diary in 1919: “Art can be a megaphone for those who cannot speak.”

;
;;
;

;She came by her conscience early, as the daughter of free-thinking parents in Königsberg (a German city that was ethnically cleansed by the Soviet army after the second world war and is now Kaliningrad, part of Russia). She was allowed to study art—hardly usual for a girl at the time—and did so in Berlin, Paris and Florence. After Kollwitz married in 1891 and settled in Berlin, her star rose quickly. In 1898 she exhibited her first cycle of etchings, “A Weavers' Revolt”. A jury awarded her a gold medal, but the Kaiser refused to bestow it, as “a medal for a woman, that would be going too far”.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The controversy made her name, but just as her career began to flourish, the first world war broke out (partly thanks to the same Kaiser's extraordinarily poor judgment). Her youngest son was killed in combat. From that point on, Kollwitz's art focused on the human costs of battle: portraits of grief, narrative series of woodcuts and etchings and eventually sculptures, including a ;Pietà ;selected in 1993 by the German government for its national monument to victims of war.

;

;Though Kollwitz was a member of the Secession, a group of artists who rejected academic tradition, she preferred the human figure and monochrome palettes to the colourful abstractions that came to define Modernism. Some Modernists, who saw painting real people, especially women, as somehow unsophisticated, dismissed her as a “social-democratic agitator”. Detractors focused on her themes and biography rather than her prodigious talent.

;
;;
;

;According to Starr Figura, the curator of the MoMA exhibition, it is high time that Kollwitz is recognised as “one of the most extraordinary draughtspeople and printmakers in history”.她是许多当代艺术家的试金石，其中包括当今最著名的画家之一克里·詹姆斯·马歇尔。 On display at ;M;o;MA; are the successive “states”, or plates of each image, which show how Kollwitz conveyed such emotional power.

;

;Meanwhile the political posters she made during the Weimar period—including the most famous, “Nie Wieder Krieg” (“Never Again War”, pictured above)—have had a long afterlife in left-wing politics. Her social-realist style led to her work being co-opted by the communist East and dismissed by the capitalist West during the cold war, the Staedel show points out.

;;O;;N JUNE 24TH; 2022 America's Supreme Court ruled, in ;Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organisation;,; ;to let states set their own laws on abortion. Since then 14 have banned abortion completely, with exceptions for extreme circumstances. The consequences of overturning ;Roe v Wade; are becoming clearer. A stark one is the sharp rise in permanent contraceptive procedures among both men, through ;vasectomies;, and women, through tubal ligations.

;;;

;In a paper published on April 12th in ;;JAMA; Health Forum;, a medical journal, researchers from the University of Pittsburgh and Boston University analysed data on permanent contraceptive procedures among 18- to 30-year-olds (see chart). They looked at 22m instances of patients attending at least one appointment, for either evaluation or treatment, in each month between January 2019 and September 2023. These were mostly at academic medical centres, so government-funded public clinics providing free family-planning services to poor people may not have been adequately represented. The results are nonetheless striking.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The; ;JAMA;; study found a sharp jump in permanent contraceptive procedures among both men and women in the months after the ;Dobbs; decision. Before ;Dobbs;, there were around 250 tubal ligations for every 100,000 women with health-care appointments per month. But immediately afterwards that number jumped by 58. In the following months, the growth rate accelerated from its baseline of 2.8 additional procedures per month in the three and a half years leading up to ;Dobbs; to more than five.

;

;Men underwent fewer contraceptive procedures to begin with. Just before the ;Dobbs; ruling, the study finds, there were around 50 vasectomies per 100,000 male outpatients per month. This rate had been steadily increasing by about one procedure per month. In the month right after ;Dobbs;, however, it jumped by 27, before reverting to its previous growth rate.

;

;What to make of these numbers? Those who had already been planning to undergo the procedure may have expedited their decisions. Some may have also feared a broader crackdown on other forms of contraception. Groups advocating the right to abortion have warned that bans from the moment of conception could be interpreted to include the morning-after pill and intrauterine devices.

;

;That would suggest that permanent contraception, rather than a temporary method, is becoming more prevalent among young people. But that carries greater risks of so-called sterilisation regret. A global review of studies in 2005 found that women who had tubal ligations at 30 or younger were eight times more likely to undergo a reversal or an evaluation for in vitro fertilisation than those who had the procedure later in life. A more recent paper, in 2022, focusing on America, found that 13% of surveyed women who had their tubes tied at 30 or younger regretted their decision, compared with 7% of women who were over 30 at the time of the procedure. The decisions that ;Dobbs; is forcing on young Americans may affect their lives in ways that were not widely anticipated. ;■;
